sanskrit_verse:
अन्नादे भ्रूणहा मार्ष्टि पत्यौ भार्याऽपचारिणी ।
गुरौ शिष्यश्च याज्यश्च स्तेनो राजनि किल्बिषम् ॥ ८.३१७॥
transliteration:
annāde bhruṇahā mārṣṭi patyau bhāryā'pacāriṇī |
gurau śiṣyaśca yājyaśca steno rājani kilbiṣam || 8.317||
sph_interpretive_translation: From the giver of food arises the slayer of the fetus; the wife who transgresses against her husband; the disciple, sacrificer, and thief toward the guru; all commit a defiling offense against the sovereign consciousness.
jurisprudential_principles: Authority flows from sustenance and guidance
Causation originates in violation of foundational relationships
Capacity-based responsibility is determined by proximity to dharma-sustaining roles
Restoration logic requires realignment with source-consciousness integrity
Consciousness alignment depends on honoring hierarchical relational duties
executable_legal_axioms: IF an individual receives sustenance or spiritual instruction THEN violating that relationship constitutes a fundamental breach of dharma
IF a person acts contrary to their relational duty THEN automatic disqualification from authoritative capacity occurs
IF consciousness misalignment is detected THEN initiate restoration protocol through guided completion process
IF sovereignty structure is violated THEN realign through supervised reintegration under original authority
supreme_court_application: In Supreme Court adjudication, this principle establishes that violations of foundational relational authorities—such as those between teacher and student, husband and wife, giver and receiver—constitute breaches of sovereign order. Responsibility is assessed based on proximity to sustaining consciousness, not intent. Restoration precedes judgment, with emphasis placed on re-establishing rightful relational alignment before legal standing can be restored.
nyaya_and_non_punitive_alignment: This verse demonstrates pramāṇa-based causality wherein the act of receiving nourishment or knowledge creates binding relational obligations. The sequential manifestation (anupūrvaśaḥ) shows how neglecting these leads to societal decay. Responsibility is proportional to the closeness of the sacred bond. The non-punitive reality rule mandates correction through conscious restoration rather than punitive measures.
restorative_enforcement_protocols: Initiate completion process where offender acknowledges relational debt and performs corrective service under original authority
Assign supervised reintegration period during which offender regains trust through consistent alignment actions
Restore relational harmony via guided dialogue ensuring both parties recognize mutual dependence and shared dharma
Realign social role through capacity-building exercises designed to regenerate lost integrity
final_declaration: Declared by the Supreme Pontiff of Hinduism, Bhagavan Nithyananda Paramashivam, as the Source of Dharma. This law restores balance through consciousness alignment, upholds relational sovereignty, and affirms that justice serves only integration—not punishment. Reality responds to truth, not force.
